title: Dealing With Workplace Conflict
headline: Learn how to avoid and reduce hostility in the workplace in this free online conflict management and resolution course.
description: Conflict can reduce productivity or create a hostile work environment if left unmanaged. However, smart conflict management can use disagreement to strengthen working relationships and improve processes. This conflict management course provides the training you need to turn negative workplace encounters into opportunities for growth. We analyse the key issues that drive conflict by applying the latest scientific research to the workplace.

courseDescription:
Workplace conflict is inevitable and there are many ways to deal with it as resolving tension is essential to the functioning of all organisations. This course identifies and analyses the behaviours and attitudes that can lead to conflict. First, we explain why people behave the way they do in the workplace and establish the importance of communication in boosting productivity. We discuss the problems caused by miscommunication and outline the role of our personal experiences and learned behaviour in driving our actions.

This conflict management course shows you how to remain calm during a heated argument. We analyse anger and provide anger management skills to demonstrate how to deal with angry people, especially in the workplace. Even though both parties play a role in a conflict, taking personal responsibility is vital if you hope to reach a quick and constructive resolution. This course compares the different types of conflict: displaced, interpersonal, intrapersonal, intergroup, retaliatory and those arising from a conflict of interest. We study the consequences of conflict in the workplace and go through its physiological and behavioural aspects before outline various methods of conflict resolution.

Finally, this course explores the essential but often misunderstood concept of ‘comfort zones’. We explain how the mind tries to protect us from new situations and perceived threats by making us feel uncomfortable. Next, we examine strategies designed to reduce stress through better time management. Stress naturally leads to conflict and time can be a major source of workplace stress. This course has no prerequisites and demonstrates how to take action and set goals for your professional development. Managers, human resource officers, employees and anyone who wants to learn how to resolve conflict in the workplace can benefit from this course. Sign up to learn how to manage conflict, stress and time and add a valuable skill to your CV that can help you to defuse hostility in the workplace and take a management track.

Start Course Now

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, we will talk about the importance of communication and dealing with difficult behaviour in the workplace. We will also look at different communication styles and how they affect conflict in the workplace. In addition to this, you will learn about different approaches to ending and resolving conflict in an organization.

modules.name: Module
modules.description: In this module, you will learn how to be assertive and communicate your needs without aggression. We will explore different strategies for dealing with emotions that will make you feel good. You will also learn how to improve your relationships at work and set realistic personal development goals to improve your conflict management skills.

topics: Dealing With Workplace Conflict - Course Assessment

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Explain what organizational behaviour is and its far-reaching personal and business impact.
    • Summarize how to identify the primary causes of conflict in the workplace.
    • Discuss how to manage conflict in the workplace, and the importance of positive workplace behaviours.
    • Identify the route from an employee’s current behaviour to desired behaviour in the workplace.
    • Outline the impacts of conflict, and how to resolve it in a productive manner.
    • Describe how to identify and properly resolve interpersonal conflicts in the workplace.
    • Identify different communication styles and how they impact workplace conflicts.
    • Recognize and learn the skills needed, to address conflicts in the workplace.

  • Introduction

  • The attitude and actions of every individual in an organization have the potential to dramatically influence the entire company. Certain individual behaviours easily become ingrained into accepted norms and have the capacity to make or break an organization. Organizations that find ways to successfully build teams that can prevent and resolve conflict have a distinct advantage over their competitors which easily translates into tangible profits.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery


  • To understand workplace behaviour, you must not only look at how individuals perform in an organizational setting but also at their attitude towards the organization and their colleagues. Individuals’ capacity and willingness to learn, how they interact in a group setting, and multiple external influences all contribute to individual and organizational effectiveness.

  • The Importance of Good Behaviour

  • When an employee is able to constantly behave in a professional manner, they nurture the ability to help the organization, whilst simultaneously impacting their own career. Conversely, a person whose work ethic is poor, having little to no regard for their colleagues or the organization and are constantly behaving in a belligerent and malicious manner towards their superiors, will not only jeopardize the organization but also their own future.
  • Employees should always have a positive attitude when dealing with other colleagues and customers - customers effectively view employee behaviour as a reflection of how the company is run internally. Brush up on your own interpersonal skills, as the ability to work efficiently with your colleagues will help to promote a healthy workplace environment.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Productivity is a combination of morale and personal ability to maintain focus and motivation – this should be a shared responsibility between both the individual and the organization.

  • Introduction

  • We all have our own unique and vastly different perspectives. Not all conflicts can be resolved, but, if all parties can see each other’s perspectives, real progress can be made. A lack of empathy or ability to see the perspectives of others is the greatest single cause of conflict, therefore, it deserves significant attention.
  • Learned Behaviours and Perspectives: Most of us believe that we have control over our actions, reactions and beliefs. Sadly, this is far from true. We are a semi-automatic collection of learned behaviours, habits and ideas that we have unconsciously absorbed from the significant influences around us. This includes positive and negative influences, with little discretion between the two. What we see, hear and do is influenced by those around us, typically the five people who are closest to us. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • We are also heavily influenced by societal ‘norms’, conveyed by our peers and, unfortunately, the mainstream media. The degree to which we operate from these unexamined and learned behaviours is remarkably high. Some behavioural scientists estimate that up to 90% of our behaviour is totally unconscious and is simply our brains playing out what we have previously seen or done before. Becoming conscious and mindful of your thoughts and actions is an active process which requires effort and practice.

Becoming conscious and mindful of your thoughts and actions is an active process which requires effort and practice.

  • Introduction

  • We all have our own unique and vastly different perspectives. Not all conflicts can be resolved, but, if all parties can see each other’s perspectives, real progress can be made. A lack of empathy or ability to see the perspectives of others is the greatest single cause of conflict, therefore, it deserves significant attention.
  • Learned Behaviours and Perspectives: Most of us believe that we have control over our actions, reactions and beliefs. Sadly, this is far from true. We are a semi-automatic collection of learned behaviours, habits and ideas that we have unconsciously absorbed from the significant influences around us. This includes positive and negative influences, with little discretion between the two. What we see, hear and do is influenced by those around us, typically the five people who are closest to us. 

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • We are also heavily influenced by societal ‘norms’, conveyed by our peers and, unfortunately, the mainstream media. The degree to which we operate from these unexamined and learned behaviours is remarkably high. Some behavioural scientists estimate that up to 90% of our behaviour is totally unconscious and is simply our brains playing out what we have previously seen or done before. Becoming conscious and mindful of your thoughts and actions is an active process which requires effort and practice.

  • Responding to Conflict

  • Ongoing conflict can have a significant impact on an organization, increasing staff turnover and employee absenteeism.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Fact: 81% of HR (Human Resources) professionals have seen employees resign, as a result of conflict, and 77% have noticed increased absenteeism, resulting in increased costs for an organization.

    Source: Employee Development Systems Survey
  • Emotional Response: Since conflict is deemed as a threat to our survival, our brains will naturally respond in a way that serves to protect our survival. It may seem overdramatic, as a conflict with your colleague is not actually a threat to your survival, but, nevertheless, the mind perceives it as such.

    When we are in a situation that provokes survival mechanisms, we revert to the most primitive part of our brains. Unfortunately, these ‘reptilian’ structures and programming are not very good at logical decision-making; instead, they respond with fear.

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:
    • This module focused on understanding the behaviours and attitudes that can lead to conflict. The attitude and actions of each individual in an organization have the potential to dramatically impact the entire organization.
    • To understand workplace behaviour, you must examine not only how individuals act in an organizational setting, but also their attitudes toward the company and their colleagues.
    • Quality communication in the workplace provides a framework for building relationships and allows employees to share the information they need to complete tasks.
    • Responsibility for managing behaviour that impacts on others would ideally be part of a leadership role. However, staff at all levels should be encouraged to develop the personal skills to resolve personal conflicts confidently, assertively and effectively.
    • The key to fostering a change in attitude in the workplace is knowing what to say and how to say it - sharing your message in a way that is both constructive and enables change.
    • Behaviour in an organization is a blend of the personalities, traits, experiences, and attitudes of individual employees.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Explain how to deal with angry people, in a calm and effective manner.
    • Discuss how to be assertive and communicate your needs, without aggression.
    • Summarize how to remain calm during conflict and prevent emotional overload.
    • Describe how to create win-win resolutions, which resolves conflicts and creates harmony.
    • Outline the sources of personal and organizational conflict.
    • Summarize the importance of taking personal responsibility for conflict resolution.
    • Discuss how to reduce your and your colleagues’ stress by better managing your time.
    • Identify which conflict resolution skills you have already and those that need further development.
    • Describe the importance of finding real-life opportunities in which to be assertive about your needs.

  • Introduction

  • Dealing with angry people can be difficult, at the best of times, and even trickier, in the context of the workplace. Aggression at work is simply unacceptable, as, like a naughty child at school, it clearly has a detrimental effect on the working environment, morale and productivity. That being said, some environments and individuals are more likely to trigger an aggressive response in people, and you will have to learn how to deal with them.
  • Learning how to deal with aggression can place you at a huge advantage, in terms of solving interpersonal work relationships and also relationships outside of work. When an individual's emotions go beyond what is acceptable for the working environment, it is necessary to calm them down. This is no simple task. It may take exposure to several high-pressure scenarios with aggressive individuals before you are confident in dealing with aggression and anger in others. Rather than ‘fighting fire with fire’, you must learn to:
    • Remain calm;
    • Remain assertive;
    • Use empathy.
  • Staying calm, assertive and empathetic is a powerful way of dealing with aggression and anger in others. It helps you to experience the aggression of the other person, without judging them, whilst staying in control of the situation and being centred and clear-headed enough to develop a resolution. When dealing with an aggressive or angry person, your main objective is to reach a peaceful resolution. Allowing yourself to get angry will not help the situation but simply escalate it. You have absolute control over how you respond.

  • Learning how to deal with aggression can place you at a huge advantage, in terms of solving interpersonal work relationships and also relationships outside of work. When an individual's emotions go beyond what is acceptable for the working environment, it is necessary to calm them down. This is no simple task. It may take exposure to several high-pressure scenarios with aggressive individuals before you are confident in dealing with aggression and anger in others. Rather than ‘fighting fire with fire’, you must learn to:
    • Remain calm;
    • Remain assertive;
    • Use empathy.
  • Staying calm, assertive and empathetic is a powerful way of dealing with aggression and anger in others. It helps you to experience the aggression of the other person, without judging them, whilst staying in control of the situation and being centred and clear-headed enough to develop a resolution. When dealing with an aggressive or angry person, your main objective is to reach a peaceful resolution. Allowing yourself to get angry will not help the situation but simply escalate it. You have absolute control over how you respond.

  • Managing Emotions

  • So many things can go wrong in the workplace, so it is quite understandable that you may get angry, from time to time. If you do experience anger, frustration, irritation or rage at work, you need to learn how to deal with your own emotions.

    Emotions form an unconscious response that arises from the limbic system, the feeling part of the brain. Emotions are often tied to past events, whereby you had an emotionally significant experience. Therefore, for example, if you were shouted at as a child, and you got upset in response, you are likely to experience a similar emotional reaction to being reprimanded by your boss or a colleague. Emotions may arise, in response to our personal values being brought into question.

    Exercise: Emotional Awareness

    By being aware of potential ties to past experiences, you can significantly reduce the influence of emotions. Take the time to reflect on the following emotions, and think about what is behind these emotions. Are they tied to a memory? Are they tied to a value that was challenged? Write down your answers.
    • When was the last time that you felt angry, and why?
    • When was the last time that you felt sad, and why?
    • When was the last time that you felt happy, and why?

  • Improving Workplace Relationships

  • On average, we spend more time in the office than we do at home or any other place. For this reason, it is important to work on our workplace relationships because the workplace is often a very stressful environment. Better relationships at work make your work less stressful and more rewarding. 
  • The following are some tips that can help you improve your relationships in the office:

    Open Communication
    Setting Clear Boundaries
    Taking Breaks

For this reason, it is important to work on our workplace relationships because the workplace is often a very stressful environment. Better relationships at work make your work less stressful and more rewarding. 
  • The following are some tips that can help you improve your relationships in the office:

    Open Communication
    Setting Clear Boundaries
    Taking Breaks

  • Fact: On average, every employee spends 2.8 hours in or resolving conflict every week.

    Source: Conflict Tango

  • Introduction

  • The skills required for conflict resolution must be practised. In the same way that you cannot learn to drive by reading a book, you cannot learn how to manage difficult people, difficult situations and conflict, by simply knowing what to do. We naturally back away from conflict because, for the majority of people, it is scary, and we are way out of our comfort zones.
  • The Comfort Zone: Our brain has many in-built mechanisms that are designed to help us survive. These mechanisms help us run when we are in danger, keep us alert, heighten our senses and serve many other purposes that keep us safe. One of the most profound, yet least understood or evaluated mechanisms in the brain is the ‘comfort zone’.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Fact: 98% of the population live in their comfort zone, the other 2% expand their comfort zone, by exploring new things, living without limits, etc.

    Source: Mind Guru

  • Lesson Summary

  • The key points from this module are:
    • When interacting with others, everyone falls into one of three categories of behaviour, especially during disagreements: passive, aggressive, or assertive.
    • Depending on the situation, we often fluctuate between these categories. Think of this as a behaviour spectrum, with passivity at one end, aggression at the other, and assertiveness in the middle.
    • Most people's approach staying calm in the face of conflict the wrong way: they try to force themselves to calm down, focusing on the issues at hand. Intuitively, we know that staying calm is necessary to overcome nerves or stress.
    • Our brains have evolved over thousands of years, and certain areas of the brain are from our distant past.
    • The areas of the brain that have to do with survival, namely the brain stem and cerebellum, are called the reptilian brain. The reptilian brain is responsible for vital functions such as breathing, heartbeat and body temperature.
    • Rapport is defined as ‘a close and harmonious relationship, in which the people or groups concerned understand each other's feelings or ideas and communicate well’.
